title: 109_hr1862
content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires mandatory drug testing for athletes in professional sports associations such as Major League Baseball, the National Basketball Association, and the National Football League. The Act is overseen by the Secretary of Commerce. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates drug testing for athletes in professional sports associations within 270 days of enactment. Testing must be random, at least once a year, without prior notification to athletes. The Secretary will issue a list of substances for testing. The Secretary will issue a list of prohibited substances for athlete testing, determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency. Testing will be conducted by an independent party, and positive results will lead to penalties such as suspension. An athlete testing positive for prohibited substances will face penalties including suspension from participation in the professional sports association for a minimum of 2 years. A repeat offense will result in permanent suspension. The name of the athlete with a positive test result will be disclosed to the public. An athlete who tests positive for prohibited substances will have their positive test result disclosed to the public. They have the right to appeal the penalty and must file an appeal within 5 days. The professional sports association must hold a hearing and reach a final decision within 30 days. Penalties will be stayed pending the appeal process. SEC. 4. EXEMPTIONS.

The Secretary may exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations from section 3.

SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

Starting 1 year after final rules from section 3, the Secretary can fine associations not following testing policies. Initial fine is $5,000,000, increasing by $1,000,000 daily.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must provide a report every 2 years on the effectiveness of regulations, compliance by professional sports associations, and instances of noncompliance. Additionally, the Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes, focusing on prohibited substance policies and testing procedures. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the prohibited substance policies and testing procedures of intercollegiate athletic associations, college and university athletic departments, and secondary schools. A report assessing the adequacy of these testing policies in detecting and preventing the use of performance-enhancing substances will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on prohibited substance policies and testing procedures in intercollegiate and interscholastic athletic associations, with recommendations to Congress on expanding regulations to these associations.
